channel.title: Bloomberg Politics

item.title: Stocks Rise on Reports Iran Wants to Restart Talks: Markets Wrap
item.description: Relative calm returned to global markets, with stocks climbing and oil sinking alongside gold as fears subsided that Israel’s war against Iran would escalate into a wider conflict. Equities extended gains on news reports Tehran is signaling it wants to restart talks over nuclear programs.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: Israeli rescuers search through the rubble at the site of an overnight Iranian missile strike in Bat Yam on June 15, 2025.

item.title: Irish State to Exit AIB, Putting Bank Into Private Ownership
item.description: The Irish state has launched its final share sale with AIB Group Plc, reducing its stake in the lender to zero and putting it into private ownership.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fletcher

media:content.media:description: An Allied Irish Banks branch in Dublin.

item.title: G-7 Works to Secure Critical Minerals in Face of China Curbs
item.description: The Group of Seven leading economies are working to shore up supplies of critical minerals as they seek to move away from reliance on China for materials used in everything from mobile phones to wind turbines.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: Bags of rare earth concentrates sit for transport at the Mountain Pass mine in Mountain Pass, California.

item.title: Trump Says Iran Wants to Talk After Waves of Israeli Strikes
item.description: President Donald Trump said Iran wants to talk about de-escalating the conflict with Israel even as the two sides exchanged deadly fire for the fourth consecutive day.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Stephanie Lai, Arsalan Shahla, Galit Altstein

media:content.media:description: Canada's Prime Minister Mark Carney speaks during a meeting with US President Donald Trump on the sidelines of the G7 Summit, in Kananaskis, Canada, on June 16. Photographer: Mark Schiefelbein/AP Photo

item.title: Trump Orders ICE to Expand Deportations in Largest Cities Including New York and Chicago
item.description: President Donald Trump directed federal officials to expand efforts to deport migrants in the largest US cities in the face of protests and court challenges, even as his administration is looking to ease the impact of the crackdown on key sectors of the American workforce.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Federal agents detain an individual following a hearing in immigration court at the Jacob K. Javitz Federal Building in New York, on June 10.

item.title: US Urges Appeals Court to Allow National Guard Troops in LA
item.description: The US Department of Justice urged a federal appeals court to overturn a lower court’s order that limits the Trump administration’s use of National Guard troops in Los Angeles in response to protests over the president’s immigration raids.
item.dc:creator: Madlin Mekelburg

media:content.media:description: California National Guard members stand in formation during a “No Kings” protest in Los Angeles, California, on June 14, 2025.

item.title: Trump Says Trade Deal With Canada Is Achievable

media:content.media:description: Attendees at the G7 Media Centre before the G7 Leaders' Summit in Banff, Alberta, on June 15. Photographer: Gavin John/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Family Launches Branded Mobile Phone Service in US
item.description: President Donald Trump’s family is getting into the mobile phone business with a Trump-branded service that will rely on pre-existing wireless networks and hardware that is “made in America.”
item.dc:creator: Kelcee Griffis, Ashley Carman

media:content.media:description: Eric Trump, from left, Don Hendrickson, Eric Thomas, Patrick O’Brien, and Donald Trump Jr. during an announcement for Trump Mobile in New York on June 16.

item.title: Russia Says US Canceled Planned Meeting on Bilateral Relations
item.description: Russia said the US canceled the next round of planned consultations aimed at removing “irritants” from their bilateral relations and restoring the work of diplomatic missions in each other’s countries.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

media:content.media:description: Visitors walk through Red Square in Moscow.

item.title: Spain’s Premier Sees No Sign of Illegal Financing in the Party
item.description: Spain’s Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said he sees no evidence of illegal financing within the Socialist Party as a corruption scandal that forced the resignation of a top aide continues to roil his government.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro, Clara Hernanz Lizarraga

media:content.media:description: Spain's prime minister Pedro Sanchez

item.title: Chile’s Toha Ratchets Up Attacks as Presidential Primary Nears
item.description: Chile presidential hopeful Carolina Toha stepped up criticism of the other contenders on the center-left during a debate Monday as her popularity fades with less than two weeks to go before a primary.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: Presidential candidate for the Party for Democracy Carolina Toha

item.title: Israeli Weapons Displays Covered at Paris Air Show, Sparking Protests
item.description: French officials blocked off the exhibits of several Israeli weapons makers at the Paris Air Show on Monday, leading to protestations and finger pointing over who was to blame.
item.dc:creator: Leen Al-Rashdan, Samy Adghirni, Siddharth Vikram Philip, Kate Duffy

media:content.media:description: A black wall blocks off the Israel pavilions, including Israel Aerospace Industries Ltd., at the Paris Air Show, on June 16.

item.title: Starmer Aims to Make Progress With Trump on UK-US Trade Pact
item.description: US President Donald Trump and UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer will meet Monday as they work to finalize a trade pact between their two nations that would be the first such deal since the White House announced a string of punitive tariffs against countries worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer speaks to the media during the G7 Leaders Summit in Kananaskis, Canada, on June 16.

item.title: Status of Iran’s Near-Bomb Grade Uranium Looms Over IAEA
item.description: The United Nations atomic watchdog convened an emergency meeting to assess Israel’s attacks on Iranian nuclear facilities, along with their disruption on oversight of the Islamic Republic’s stockpile of near-bomb grade uranium.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone

media:content.media:description: Satellite view of the Isfahan enrichment facility following Israeli airstrikes in Iran, on Jun 14, 2025.

item.title: Xi Pushes to Deepen Central Asia Influence With Kazakh Visit
item.description: Chinese President Xi Jinping has arrived in Kazakhstan for talks with Central Asian leaders, providing a counterpoint to a Group of Seven summit by visiting a vast region at the nexus of competing interests from Washington to Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Nariman Gizitdinov

media:content.media:description: Chinese President Xi Jinping and his Kazakh counterpart Kassym-Jomart Tokayev.

item.title: Mali to Take Control of Key Barrick Gold Mine for Six Months
item.description: A Malian court ruled that Barrick Mining Corp.’s Loulo-Gounkoto gold mining complex should be placed under provisional administration for six months, handing control of one of the Canadian company’s biggest operations to state-appointed management.
item.dc:creator: Katarina Hoije, Diakaridia Dembele

media:content.media:description: Dumper trucks collect rock ore from from the digging floor in a section of the Loulo-Gounkoto gold mining complex. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

item.title: Budapest Mayor to Stage Pride Parade Over Orban’s Opposition
item.description: Budapest’s mayor said the Hungarian capital would organize this year’s Pride parade under its own auspices to shield it from attempts by national authorities to ban the LGBTQ event.
item.dc:creator: Zoltan Simon

media:content.media:description: Gergely Szilveszter Karácsony, mayor of Budapest, speaks during a Pride celebration in Brussels in May.

item.title: Kenya Police Boss Steps Down for Murder Probe Amid Protests
item.description: Kenya’s Deputy Inspector General Eliud Lagat agreed to “step aside” to allow for a probe to be carried out into the death of a man while in police custody.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

media:content.media:description: Protesters block traffic during a march over the death of blogger Albert Ojwang in Nairobi, on June 9.

item.title: Israel Strikes Continue Amid Reports Iran Keen to De-Escalate
item.description: Israel and Iran exchanged fire for the fourth consecutive day on Monday, stoking fears of an all-out war with the potential to drag in others in the oil-rich region and force the US into a more hands-on stance.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla, Galit Altstein

media:content.media:description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei in 2024.

item.title: Suspect in Shootings of Minnesota Lawmakers Is Apprehended
item.description: The man suspected of killing a Democratic state lawmaker and her husband in Minnesota has been arrested and will appear in court Monday.
item.dc:creator: Bob Van Voris

media:content.media:description: FBI agents in a neighborhood in Green Isle, Minnesota, on June 15. Photographer: Stephen Maturen/Getty Images

item.title: EU’s Sefcovic to Meet US’s Greer at G-7 to Talk Trade, Tariffs
item.description: European Union trade chief Maros Sefcovic is expected to meet with US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer on the sidelines of the Group of Seven meeting in Alberta, Canada, according to a person familiar with the plan.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: Maros Sefcovic Photographer: Jean-Christophe Verhaegen/Getty Images

item.title: Oil Drops on Signs Conflict May Spare Iranian Crude Production
item.description: Oil fell as the conflict in the Middle East has so far avoided disrupting crude production and the Wall Street Journal reported that Iran privately expressed willingness to deescalate hostilities with Israel.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: Vehicles jam a highway as a fire blazes nearby in the Shahran in Tehran on June 15, 2025. Photographer: Atta Kenare/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Latvia Questions Party Leader for Russian Comments in Parliament
item.description: Latvian authorities detained and questioned the leader of a political party catering to the country’s Russian-speaking minority for allegedly inciting hatred in parliament earlier this month.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Eglitis

media:content.media:description: Aleksejs Roslikovs

item.title: EU Faces Struggle to Cut Russia Oil Price Cap on Mideast Risk
item.description: The European Union faces an uphill struggle to lower the Russian oil price cap after US opposition at the Group of Seven summit and a crude price spike driven by Iran-Israel tensions.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Alberto Nardelli, Ewa Krukowska

item.title: Algeria Opens Door to Larger Foreign Role in Mining Projects
item.description: Algeria’s parliament approved legislation allowing foreign companies to own as much of 80% of mining projects, a step change for the OPEC country seeking to diversify its economy.
item.dc:creator: Salah Slimani

media:content.media:description: Mining operations. Photographer: Ian Waldie/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump’s Higher-Ed Fight Comes for Public Schools in States That Voted for Him
item.description: Arizona State University President Michael Crow is proud that his school is home to more international students — about 17,000 — than any other public institution in the US.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Albright, Francesca Maglione, Elizabeth Rembert, Ann Choi

media:content.media:description: The Arizona State University campus in Tempe, Arizona. Photographer: Matt York/AP Photo

item.title: Israel’s Air Shield Is Tested Like Never Before as Iran Fires Ballistic Missiles
item.description: As Iran fires masses of ballistic missiles, Israel’s vaunted air defenses are being tested like never before.
item.dc:creator: Paul Wallace, Galit Altstein

item.title: Carney Flexes Economy-First Foreign Policy as G-7 Meets in Canada
item.description: As Mark Carney prepares to host world leaders at the Group of Seven summit in western Canada, he’s showing off a foreign policy that’s more hardheaded than that of Justin Trudeau.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt, Laura Dhillon Kane

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney in Ottawa, Canada on June 14.

item.title: Trump’s Budget Cuts Prompt China to Review Risks of US Data Void
item.description: China’s government is reviewing the fallout for the nation’s scientific research from President Donald Trump’s moves to withdraw funding from some US agencies and halt publication of certain categories of data.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao

media:content.media:description: Photo by Brendan Smialowski/AFP/Getty Images Photographer: BRENDAN SMIALOWSKI/AFP

item.title: US Allies and Adversaries Are Dodging Trump’s Tariff Threats
item.description: Leaders aren’t racing to make deals despite White House pressure.
item.dc:creator: Wes Kosova
